stem: The physician orders a continuous infusion of heparin at 1600 units/hour for Mr. Davies. The pharmacy provides a heparin solution of 25,000 units in 250 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride. What rate, in mL/hour, should the nurse program the infusion pump to deliver?

rationale.correct: The correct rate is 16 mL/hour. To calculate the infusion rate, use the formula: (Desired dose / Concentration on hand) x Volume. In this case, (1600 units/hour / 25,000 units) x 250 mL = 16 mL/hour. Accurate medication calculation is vital for patient safety, especially with high-alert medications like heparin.

mnemonic.title: Desired Over Have
mnemonic.expansion: Desired (what you want) divided by Have (what you have available) then multiply by the Vehicle (volume).

rationale.incorrect: Incorrect answers result from errors in setting up or solving the proportion. Option 1 (10 mL/hour) underestimates the required dose. Option 2 (12 mL/hour) and Option 4 (20 mL/hour) also represent miscalculations and will not deliver the prescribed heparin dose, potentially leading to subtherapeutic anticoagulation or over-anticoagulation, respectively.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap lies in the multiple steps involved in correctly setting up and solving the proportion, and potential carelessness in identifying the correct units and volume.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully review the order, identify the desired dose and the concentration on hand, and double-check the units to ensure they are consistent. Use a systematic approach to medication calculation.

clinicalPearls: Always double-check medication calculations with another nurse, especially for high-alert medications like heparin.
Use a standardized formula for medication calculations to minimize errors.
Be aware of the concentration of the medication on hand to ensure accurate dosing.

itemContext.sbar: S: Arthur Davies, a 68-year-old male, is admitted for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left lower extremity. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. O: At 07:00, the patient reported increased pain and swelling in his left leg. His vital signs are: BP 160/90 mmHg, HR 98 bpm, RR 20 breaths/min, Temp 37.2°C, SpO2 94% on room air. He is alert and oriented. A: The DVT appears to be worsening despite initial subcutaneous heparin anticoagulation therapy. A new order was received for a continuous heparin infusion at 1600 units/hour. Current aPTT is 38 seconds. R: Please verify the new order for the continuous heparin infusion and initiate it. Monitor aPTT every 6 hours and adjust the heparin infusion rate according to the established hospital protocol. Assess pain and swelling in his left leg every 4 hours. Notify the physician for aPTT values greater than 90 seconds or any signs of bleeding. The next dose of warfarin is scheduled for 20:00.
